Theorem 4.28: Let A be an m × n matrix, and let R0 in REF(j1, j2, . . . , jr) be the result of Gauss-Jordan elimination on A. Then the first r rows of R0 form a basis of the row space R(A), and dim(R(A)) = r = rank(A). Proof. R0 = M A, R(A) = R(R0). Basis of R(R0) can be read off: R0 ends with m − r zero rows ⇒ the first r rows span R(R0) and are linearly independent (private nonzeros at the “downward steps”). By Lemma 3.22, r = rank(A). Theorem 4.35: Let A be an m × n matrix, and let R0 in REF(j1, j2, . . . , jr) be the result of Gauss-Jordan elimination on A. Let R in RREF(j1, j2, . . . , jr) be the submatrix of R0 consisting of the first r rows. The vectors v1, v2, . . . .vn−r as constructed in Lemma 4.34 form a basis of N(A) = N(R0) = N(R), and therefore, dim(N(A)) = n − r = n − rank(A). Let x be some solution of Ax = b. Then Sol(A, b) = {x + v : v ∈ N(A)}. “Basis” of Sol(A, b): some solution x (if it exists) and a basis of N(A). Proof. (i) Sol(A, b) ∋ y = x + v︸︷︷︸ ∈N(A): y = x + (y − x) ︸ ︷︷ ︸ v , Av = Ay − Ax = b − b = 0. (ii) y = x + v︸︷︷︸ ∈N(A) ∈ Sol(A, b): Ay = Ax + Av = b + 0 = b. If there is a solution, Sol(A, b) has “dimension” n − r = dim(N(A)). r = m: there is always a solution (Lemma 4.41). r < m: “typically”, no solution. 4
